prüfeconomic opportunity cost refers to the next best alternative that is forgone when a choice is made. In other words, it is the value of the next best option that is not chosen. This concept is used to measure the cost of a decision in terms of the benefits that could have been gained from the next best alternative.

For example, if a farmer chooses to plant wheat on a particular field, the opportunity cost would be the value of the crops that could have been grown on that field if it had been planted with a different crop, such as corn or soybeans. ackage curves are graphical representations of the relationship between the quantity demanded and the price of a good or service. The demand curve is a downward-sloping curve that shows how the quantity demanded changes in response to changes in the price of the good or service. The supply curve, on the other hand, is an upward-sloping curve that shows how the quantity supplied changes in response to changes in the price of the good or service. The point at which the demand and supply curves intersect is called the equilibrium price and quantity.
